description: Proofs involving Big O, Omega, and Theta notation

blocks.latex: \text{To show } f(n) = \Theta(g(n)) \text{, we need to show } f(n) = O(g(n)) \text{ and } f(n) = \Omega(g(n)).
f(n) = {{complexity}}(g(n)) \text{ if there exist positive constants } c_1 \text{ and } n_0 \text{ such that } 0 {{op}} f(n) {{op}} c_1g(n) \text{ for all } n {{op}} n_0.
f(n) = {{complexity}}(g(n)) \text{ if there exist positive constants } c_2 \text{ and } n_0 \text{ such that } 0 {{op}} c_2g(n) {{op}} f(n) \text{ for all } n {{op}} n_0.
\text{Consider } f(n) = n^2 + n^3 \text{ and } g(n) = n^3.
\text{For O-notation: } n^2 + n^3 {{op}} n^3 + n^3 \text{ (for } n {{op}} 1 \text{)}
\text{So, } c_1 = 2, n_0 = 1 \text{ satisfies } n^2 + n^3 \le c_1n^3.
\text{For } \Omega \text{-notation: We need } c_2n^3 \le n^2 + n^3.
\text{Since } n^2 \ge 0 \text{, then } n^3 \le n^2 + n^3 \text{ for } n \ge 1 \text{.}
\text{So, } c_2 = 1, n_0 = 1 \text{ satisfies } c_2n^3 \le n^2 + n^3.
\text{Therefore, } n^2 + n^3 = {{complexity}}(n^3).
\text{To show } f(n) = {{complexity}}(g(n)) \text{, we need to find positive constants } c \text{ and } n_0 \text{ such that } 0 {{op}} f(n) {{op}} cg(n) \text{ for all } n {{op}} n_0.
\text{Consider } f(n) = \log n \text{ and } g(n) = n.
\text{We know that } \log n {{op}} n \text{ for all } n {{op}} 1.
\text{This can be proven by induction or by observing that} \text{ the exponential function grows faster than any polynomial.}
\text{Therefore, } \log n \le 1 \cdot n \text{ for all } n \ge 1.
\text{So, } c = 1 \text{ and } n_0 = 1 \text{ satisfy the definition.}
\text{Therefore, } \log n = O(n).
\text{To show } f(n) = O(g(n)) \text{, we need to find positive constants } c \text{ and } n_0 \text{ such that } 0 \le f(n) \le cg(n) \text{ for all } n \ge n_0.
\text{Consider } f(n) = n \log n \text{ and } g(n) = n^2.
\text{We need to show that } n \log n \le c \cdot n^2 \text{ for some constants } c \text{ and } n_0.
\text{Dividing both sides by } n \text{ (assuming } n > 0 \text{): } \log n \le c \cdot n.
\text{We know that } \log n < n \text{ for all } n \ge 1.
\text{Therefore, } \log n \le 1 \cdot n \text{ for all } n \ge 1.
\text{Multiplying both sides by } n: n \log n \le n^2 \text{ for all } n \ge 1.
\text{So, } c = 1 \text{ and } n_0 = 1 \text{ satisfy the definition.}
\text{Therefore, } n \log n = O(n^2).
\text{To show } f(n) \neq O(g(n)) \text{, we need to show that} \text{ for any positive constants } c \text{ and } n_0 \text{, there exists } n \ge n_0 \text{ such that } f(n) > cg(n).
\text{Consider } f(n) = 2^n \text{ and } g(n) = n^3.
\text{Assume for contradiction that } 2^n = O(n^3) \text{, so } 2^n \le c \cdot n^3 \text{ for some } c > 0 \text{ and all } n \ge n_0.
\text{Taking logarithms: } n \le \log(c \cdot n^3) = \log c + 3 \log n.
\text{Rearranging: } n - 3 \log n \le \log c.
\text{But } \lim_{n \to \infty} (n - 3 \log n) = \infty \text{ since } n \text{ grows faster than } \log n.
\text{This means } n - 3 \log n \text{ can be arbitrarily large, contradicting } n - 3 \log n \le \log c.
\text{Therefore, our assumption is false, and } 2^n \neq O(n^3).
